sentences: Yahoo’s boss, Marissa Mayer, could collect a total of $137m if she leaves the company following the sale to Verizon.
It is unclear what effect, if any, the breach will have on Yahoo’s sale price.

The security breach is yet another bruise for the aging tech firm and chief executive Marissa Mayer, who joined Yahoo in 2012 to effect a turnaround and ended up having to sell the firm’s core assets instead.
Disclosure of the breach comes two months after Yahoo, once among the most powerful tech companies in Silicon Valley, said it would sell its core internet business to telecom giant Verizon for $4.

The hack of Yahoo, still one of the internet’s busiest sites with one billion monthly users, also has   implications for both consumers and one of America’s largest companies, Verizon Communications, which is in the process of acquiring Yahoo for $4.
chastised Yahoo for not reporting suspicions of a breach sooner and called on the federal government to impose stricter disclosure requirements for companies.

8bn it sold itself to Verizon for.
The sample contained valid Yahoo user accounts, but it was unclear whether the data was from a breach of a   service or Yahoo itself.
In July, Verizon said it would acquire the internet pioneer, roughly a month before Yahoo security experts started looking into whether the site had been hacked.
Yahoo learned of the incident in July, the same month it announced its deal with Verizon, a person familiar with the matter said, speaking on condition of anonymity to freely discuss the issue.
Verizon said Thursday it learned of the breach “within the last two days” but that it had few details.
” The hack, which affected roughly half of all of Yahoo’s users, has raised serious questions about Yahoo’s security and its executives ability to deal with the fallout.
” Yahoo declined to respond to Verizon’s comments and did not say how the hack and ongoing investigation may affect the deal.
The impact on Verizon’s deal with Yahoo was not immediately clear.

Analyst Robert Peck of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey said the breach probably was not enough to prompt Verizon to abandon its deal with Yahoo, but it could call for a price decrease of $100 million to $200 million, depending on how many users leave Yahoo.
Yahoo, which was worth $125bn at the height of the dotcom bubble in 1999, was forced to reveal “state sponsored” hackers had stolen data from more than half a billion people across the world.
The attack on Yahoo was unprecedented in size, more than triple other large attacks on sites such as eBay Inc ( ) and it comes to light at a difficult time for Yahoo.
” In 2012, Yahoo had more than 1 billion user accounts in its databases.
A source close to the investigation told BuzzFeed News that Yahoo investigated Peace’s claim in July 2016 and found no direct evidence to substantiate it.
Yahoo first found out about the security breach when Vice journalist Joseph Cox contacted the company on 30 July to warn it that the data was being offered around for sale.
An annual report by the Ponemon Institute in July found that the costs to remediate a data breach is $221 per stolen record.
When asked, Yahoo declined to say whether it first learned of the hack before or after that deal was announced.

The first sign that something was amiss appeared in June, when a Russian hacker who goes by the user name Tessa88 started mentioning, in underground web forums, a new trove of stolen Yahoo data, Mr Holden said.

Yahoo’s probe of the breach  —   the biggest ever in terms of the number of accounts affected  —   turned up no evidence that hackers got   data or bank account information, it said, noting it doesn’t store that on the affected network.

Yahoo did not disclose its earlier findings about the purported Peace hack, which may have comforted users, because it believed the information may have affected the second investigation, the source said.

”This is the biggest data breach ever,” said   cryptologist Bruce Schneier, adding that the impact on Yahoo and its users remained unclear because many questions remain, including the identity of the   hackers behind it.
Although the attack happened in 2014, Yahoo only discovered  the incursion after August reports of a separate breach.

At the time it said Yahoo was “committed to protecting the security of our users’ information and we take any such claim very seriously.

According to the Ponemon Institute, which tracks data breaches, the average time it takes organizations to identify such an attack is 191 days, and the average time to contain a breach is 58 days after discovery.
Yahoo said it’s notifying affected users and has taken steps to secure their accounts, including asking potentially affected users to change their passwords.
On its website on Thursday, Yahoo encouraged users to change their passwords but did not require it.

US politicians attacked Yahoo for not acting faster to warn users, who will have to change not just their Yahoo password but also any linked accounts which could include social media profiles, photo album sites and financial services.

The data breach, which experts suggest could have been carried out by Russian, Chinese or North Korean sponsored hackers, could end up costing Yahoo more than the $4.

Shortly after Cox warned Yahoo about the existence of the data, some of it was listed for sale on   dark website the Real Deal Marketplace for sale for for three bitcoins (about $1, 860).
In early August, a hacker by the same name had listed data from 200 million Yahoo accounts for sale on the Dark Web.

The Yahoo intrusion stands out for the sheer scale of the customers apparently affected, a legacy of the company’s   position for Internet users who turned to the company for web searches, email accounts, user groups and news reports.

SAN FRANCISCO  —   Yahoo announced on Thursday that the account information of at least 500 million users was stolen by hackers two years ago, in the biggest known intrusion of one company’s computer network.
Please follow the steps below, NEWS BRIEF A “  actor” stole personal data from at least 500 million Yahoo user accounts, the troubled tech company said Thursday.

Yahoo on Thursday reported the largest data breach in history    affecting at least 500 million user accounts    months after first detecting signs of an intrusion that the company blamed on ” ” hackers.

In August, a hacker called “Peace” appeared in online forums, offering to sell 200 million of the company’s usernames and passwords for about $1, 900 in total.

Then, in August, a second hacker who goes by the alias Peace of Mind began offering a large collection of stolen Yahoo credentials  —   including user names, easily cracked passwords, birth dates, ZIP codes and email addresses  —   on a site called TheRealDeal, where hackers can buy and sell stolen data, Mr Holden said.
